text: so thank you for having me I'm happy to be here today I think I'll dive right in and really
start off by saying the work that I'll talk about today is in what I'm largely framing as digital civics and when I
talk about digital civics there's really two things that I'm interested in here and it's the intersection between what's
happening around smart cities and the ways in which data and instrumentation are starting to change how we think
about the way cities operate and the kinds of information we can glean about the infrastructures that we have whether
those infrastructures are physical like the power grid or the transportation system or whether those infrastructures
are kind of softer and about the people and the residents that live in a city I'm also interested in the ways in which
digital democracy are starting to come in contact with this so thinking about how technology is changing the ways in
which we interact with our systems of governance on a local and national scale but looking beyond just the moment of
kind of ritualized democratic participation like voting and and more the kind of everyday mundane
interactions that we have and how that we and how we interact with the you know municipal entities city agencies and
different institutions that that kind of take place and take shape in our lives across both of these I think the thing
that's important or the thing that's shared is this idea of data right when I
think about data in the sense of digital civics and in the sense of smart cities I really do you think about a beach and
sand because when you go to the beach you all often find that everything that
you encounter is also an encounter with sand in some way right it's maybe the
warm soft feeling between your feet and your toes or maybe it's that annoyance of the the stuff that comes back home
with you and your bag or and you're in your beach towel but no matter what the
sand is very much a part of the beach and the same way that data is very much a part of the smart City right is it is the material of the of the thing the
other piece of this is participation right and this is this is where the idea of Digital democracy starts to ikan and
the ways in which that we participate with each other with our community whether that's showing up at a public
meeting and having a conversation about the kinds of issues we care about and you know rallying around issues that
that we want to have our elected officials take action on I think we're seeing a resurgence of this kind of
participation recently but when we bring these together this idea that well if we
have data and we have participation then we can construct and we can start to build new kinds of cities and this idea
that these are our smart cities right and that this is in fact what we can have right if we take if we take the
material of the smart city and we apply ourselves to it with care that we can
create these these very beautiful kind of idyllic institutions and I've I like
this I mean I like sand castles sand castles are very nice but the reality of the smart city is more like this all
right it's a bunch of silos of things that are somewhat next to each other they're
often kind of crumbling perhaps not well integrated right not the kind of
beautiful monolithic architecture that we might imagine but also very
importantly they're always at risk of being washed away by the tide all right they're right the precarity of this
smart city is is very much a reality of it right and so the challenge here is is
that thinking about local governments even at the cities at the scale of a city they're large and they're
ever-changing right administration's come and go different contracts with with outside
vendors for different services come and go legacy systems are constantly in use and so the challenge of actually making
use of the data making use of that sand to create something new is always just
kind of lurking around and what we want to do in thinking about digital civics is looking at how do we take kind of the
the material that we have at hand and the in the modes of participation that we might encourage and create more
sustainable forms of organizations and of interaction and participation that
enable us to move forward and solve some of the pressing problems that cities are facing today
so the the first thing that I would say about this is in in some ways it's really about thinking about thinking
through the challenges of different forms of governance right not just about deliberation and the mode of kind of
rational problem-solving right but but thinking through the longer tail of activities that happen after a moment of
deliberation say at a public meeting as well as the activities that need to happen beforehand as people prepare for
and become informed about different issues and one of the challenges with in HCI and with the kinds of work that I
think typically happens is it we've there's a history of really looking at this moment of deliberative action right
we've there's a legacy of systems that look at how do we take computational
systems and other artifacts and help people deliberate and understand an issue understand the consequences of
decisions and work across different kinds of community boundaries to really you know work through a problem and come
to a solution but that's a really small and in many ways privilege mode and it's also very much tied to the kinds of
professional practices of public administration right where the challenges of safe fixing or dealing
with a transportation problem are put into technical terms where it's about understanding traffic flows and Road
widths and how do you operationalize and optimize within that space the other
part of what what governance relies on right is really fundamentally participation right in how do people
come together and when do they come together to actually be in the room and work through the problem and then
certainly participation is necessary within this mode of governance right and
it's something that I talk about in another work when I when I work through the kind of theoretical perspective of
public's and the ways that people participate together to identify a shared issue and then work through
different design processes to address and respond to that issue but it's
through this this mode of participation then that we can say well when people come together in public meetings they're identifying kind of the common good that
they want to work for I mean then they're working collectively to try to achieve that but again just as
governance requires participation participation requires engagement
and an engagement is really about how do you how do you motivate people right what is that either incentive system or
what is the issue that gets people out of bed to say okay something something's up here that I need to address and if we
if we look at kind of HCI literature on on systems that help with and work within the Digital democracy space
they're very much focused on the kinds of deliberative mode of working but if
we look at literature and community engagement what they what they start to point out is that in fact engagement
really only happens when a group of people are identifying and responding to an injustice right and that it's that
moment of almost a friction that becomes the the cause for getting engaged all
right and this then becomes attention and I think an interesting point of where we might start to rethink both the
metaphors in the interfaces for the kinds of interfaces we would build around digital civics right so at the at
the end of governance is where we have the kind of public administrator right
and and this is the person who's been trained within a specific domain they have very particular professional
practices often those practices are around both framing a problem in a kind
of in a rational and technical way so that it's something that they know when there's a solution to it but then also
when it comes time to work with communities and have the kind of public participation activities these are built
around avoiding or at least tamping down conflict right so the public meeting is
I think a great example where people come together and can be very animated but when it becomes very contentious
that meeting breaks down very quickly and it gets shut down right and we have plenty of examples from this past week
of how that's how conflict has been avoided in these in these kinds of public spaces this mode of conflict
avoidance is in fact like you know is part of like their job right this is how they do the thing that they're doing they need to solve a problem they need
some public input and as they get that public input they want to move through to the next step right as anybody who
has a job to do and wants to go home at 5:00 p.m. to their family or to wherever else they might be wanting to do it's in some ways you can be very
sympathetic to that but an engaged public they want conflict and if that conflict is what gets them out of bed
and gets them participating and so what scholars and community engagement have really started to talk about is it well
this idea of deliberation and this idea of persuasion which is another kind of key piece in the way that some of us
think about these technologies that those are actually kind of contra to
this idea of supporting engagement that which you want you don't want persuasion because an audience that is persuaded is
an audience that is disengaged right it's being okay with the status quo in some sense so then how do we think about
different modes of community engagement and different systems that we might build that take as a as an input or take
as a kind of way of being in the world this notion of conflict and and
confronting injustice but then move it through so that that that action is then
again legible to the professional side where you're working with people who are either elected or employed in local
governments so this is really the work that I'm doing now and I'll I'll talk a
lot more specifically as I get into some recent work that I've been doing with the city of Atlanta but really to say
that community engagement is really fundamental if we want to think about digital civics and we want to think about the Smart City as a place where
people and technology are participating to create and of a new urban environment right and that it's not just about
persuading people to use or to produce data or to change their behaviors within
kind of regimes of sustainability and environmentalism but really to say okay how do we identify issues and help
people organize themselves around those issues to take action and and do so in a
way that that isn't just about deliberation so in October of last year
we launched with the city of Atlanta the Atlanta community engagement playbook
this was a product of over 18 months of work within the city of Atlanta to
rethink and rework at a city scale what and community engagement meant both
across multiple departments within kind of the mean infrastructure of Atlanta but also
looking at the community organizations neighborhood associations and how they kind of come together right and thinking
about this mode what are the different intersections of community engagement across the city what precipitated this
was the construction of the new Falcon stadium it's much further along now
today than then this picture that I have for you the current one is the yes the
one at the top this so the new stadium is next to the old stadium the old
stadium is on top of a pariah sorry a prior stadium so since the 1970s there
have been three stadia built in this community and what's happened is that
that the the neighborhood that the stadiums are sited in is a historically
important traditionally black community within Atlanta that is also very much economically and physically distressed
so very low rates of owner occupancy lots of vacant housing and many of the
kind of common and understandable social ills that that follow poverty and
distress no matter where you are the other thing that I think doesn't get
captured by this picture is that where the stadium is sited is is on top of two
former african-american churches in Atlanta one of which was the first
african-american Baptist Church in the city so it's not just about being sited
in neighborhoods that are distressed and also facing gentrification but that it was also displacing kind of very
important cultural institutions within those communities so as as this this
project was kind of coming to the fore in 2014 when it really became clear that
it was going to happen and it was going to happen here the community and the city started to work through this idea
of how do we actually you know return some benefit to the community and as
with many of these large kind of projects there's something called a community benefits agreement that gets negotiated and typically these are these
are the kinds of agreements that say that things like windfall employment we return to the community some portion of the local residents will be hired in
construction jobs or in vending jobs following the opening that there'll be job placement and training programs that
there might be some other kinds of built environment changes so that the construction would would have specific
requirements around traffic mitigation or improved infrastructure for water and sewage and this process really broke
down in the city of Atlanta and it broke down and for for lots of reasons but I
think the result of that was that decades of kind of erosion of neighborhood you know trust and and kind
of faith within local government meant that on both sides there was just no there was no mode to
come together right and injustice was seen everywhere and so there was there was confrontation right and and with
with that confrontation meant that there was no mode to come to this moment of deliberation that would have enabled the
kind of outcome of a shared or you know at least mutually agreed to agreement a
benefits plan sorry have any legal
rights here insensitive what was it do
they actually have any sort of bargaining power so the bargaining power they had was
through that churches so they didn't you this this was the first time I think ever in Atlanta's history that they
didn't use eminent domain to take the land and the prior stadia as they did the challenge was even though the the
challenge was the the churches that were there institutionally that they burned that the city purchased the land from were actually serving diaspora for you
know people who used to live in the community but we're coming back on Sundays and it wasn't actually they weren't actually serving the communities
directly but there was still this very strong cultural identity to it and so you know this becomes the complicated
history of kind of race and development in Atlanta where the institutions that
kind of exists in some of the urban core areas don't necessarily serve the
immediate neighborhood because that the shifting demographics and the shifting populations kind of over the over the
previous decades so they did not have a lot of power though their ability to stop or
forestall this process was very limited and in the fracturing within the community organizations or across the
community organizations about trying to identify what what in fact that shared goal was was a challenge which is partly
why we started with this process you look at Facebook and its users or
mechanical turk in the workers it's sort of like everything is essentially eminent domain where it's like well we're changing the platform right
and like what power do you actually have to tap on this none really sytems well I
think this is why this this mode of professional versus non-professional I think is important because that the the
professional side of say public administration where its technical problem solving right is is very much
about well we're gonna we're going to take these things and we're gonna we're gonna bracket the kind of political
power struggles that go on and we're just gonna focus on how do we up you know optimize this thing whatever that
thing might be and the engagement piece is really about those political and power struggles and so how do you that's
the kind of transition like where these modes of encounter happening and how do you move between them for it's the power
struggle and then the power struggle kind of turns into something that people can then start to to work on together
yep and so to come back to where we were the let's see where the the idea here
was that the city was provided or was awarded a grant from an organization called living cities to rethink
community engagement across the city and really starting with and focusing on the five neighborhoods directly around the
stadium and I really wanted to do what we wanted to do was develop a community led partnership to reestablish
meaningful engagement between the city of Atlanta and the West Side neighborhoods and there are four things
that we did to try to tackle this over the course of 18 months so first was
really to understand the landscape who's there that we wanted to understand what were the engagement practices in the
city understand the the experiences of being engaged within the community and then to design some response having
having done that and so in understanding the landscape really it was a period of
about six months to going around to community meetings getting shouted out of a few commissioning community
meetings and talking to people about what's happening right so I think there was an inclination at the beginning of
the project to go out and do an oral history style intervention to say let's collect stories from the from the
neighborhood to understand their history and to preserve it with I think the notion that if there's a fear of
gentrification and displacement that doing some work to record and document the history of the people that are there
becomes a way to you know palliative for that fear but what we realized very
quickly was that other groups were doing that already and they were doing it in a very local and kind of internally
focused way that felt more authentic and and coming in as kind of a representative of the city in that mode
was very it was not productive and so instead we step we took a step back and
said okay well who's here right who are the key actors whether that's community organizations different development
corporations different churches the universities Georgia Tech as well as kind of the Atlanta University Center
University so spell a Spelman Morehouse Morehouse College of Medicine Clark and
really understand how are they working together or not and how do we have a conversation with each of those
stakeholders about what might come next once we've done that we then started to
work more directly with community members that we had identified through different neighborhood associations and
we we trained a group of residents to do interviews with city city officials and
employees and so over the kind of the next I guess there's about three months we had for community residents as well
as a couple of my graduate students go out and interview close to 50 employees
of the city of Atlanta so from watershed management to Parks and Recreation to Public Safety through some of the
development organizations so really looking at what are the practices of community
engagement so when watershed management says they do community engagement what does that mean for them on a day to day basis
right when Public Safety says that they're doing community engagement what does that mean and really trying to
understand the breadth of this practice right in some cases community engagement means simply we're going to print out a
flyer and we're going to stick it in people's mailboxes all right we're going to make it available at a public meeting in other cases community engagement was
much more participatory where there was a sense of we're bringing people into the planning process as early as we can
and then we're providing opportunities for that to continue throughout as the plan develops right and the planning
department was in the midst of starting to ramp up a master planning process in the city of Atlanta so they were talking
about things in those terms this gave us a really broad sense of what community
engagement is and how it works and what we might want to do with it the other
piece of this was understanding the experience of being engaged and so we
held a couple of workshops the first of which was about a hundred and twenty
people showed up from the neighborhoods and we ran through a series of exercises to understand when they were engaged by
the city what was that like and what would what was the city engaging them with often it was about you know
infrastructure failures or other kinds of service delivery breakdowns and that being engaged was about trying to
address or redress those those service breakdowns but it was also about the kinds of routine modes of engagement
that happened through the kind of official and institutional channels so Atlanta has something called the neighborhood planning unit it's a
collection of kind of geographic regions in the city that are meant to be where local decisions are made around zoning
and other planning and this is really the primary kind of point of interface between city governance and residents
where they come together and say well either plans are presented or different zoning decisions are made
and kind of presented to the community for feedback and input in this case we
had a different set of community members that we had trained so about ten and all
they went and interviewed a total of about forty five other residents to understand more broadly what's going on
in their neighborhood so to understand both how does community engagement happen and what does that experience
like right we had a total of about eighty interviews across both kind of sides of this done by community
residents so it wasn't you know just kind of academics and scholars coming in and say I'm gonna do this research
project but it was really about building out this conversation with both city
employees and residents to understand what this practice looks like and how it unfolds and kind of in and affects
people's lives I think one of the really important things that came out of this was it as this design process move
forward and as the individuals we were working with did these interviews they started to really develop a sense of
empathy for how hard it is on both sides and if looking back at the beginning when we were getting shouted out of
community meetings one of the things that would happen often is you know the city needs to fix what they're doing
like one or the community needs to do something better one side was blaming the other for why it wasn't working but
then through this process we started to essentially kind of cultivate a capacity for empathy about how difficult
community engagement is anyway and then build some advocacy within the community that recognized that and was able to
talk to their own constituents to say no actually it didn't work because of this and but now that we know why it didn't
work we can start to understand how to do it differently so following all that
in the middle of the kind of middle half of the summer we began a 12-week very
intensive design process where we were meeting at least once a week for usually
at least three hours at a time with about 15 community members to
really talk about okay now that we understand what's going on in terms of community engagement on both sides how
do we address it how do we identify the key breakdowns how do we then think about strategies and techniques for
addressing those breakdowns and also how do we understand and what the that kind of the key obligations and values are for what good
engagement looks like why does it matter what should the outcome be you know how do you how do you go and do that and
what we ended up with was this community engagement playbook so this was released
in October as I mentioned and it's really divided into two parts maybe three parts so one part is kind of
general information about the city of Atlanta so for for residents who may not be familiar with kind of the governance
structure and how it works we have some of that information but then there's a set of plays that are really dedicated
to community organizations the neighborhood associations the small kind
of issue focused nonprofits to say here are the strategies and techniques that
you might deploy to mobile ought to identify your constituency to mobilize your base and then to do work going
forward right recognizing that there was in some sense a gap in the capacities of
some of the local organizations where some of them were very sophisticated and been operating for a long time others
were just getting started and trying to figure out how to do it but one of the challenges that we saw kind of universally was that coalition building
was very hard and some of that was for structural reasons and that there was very scarce resources and so a
willingness to work together was in some ways not possible because there was
competition for those scarce resources but by laying this out in the playbook and saying here's what happens when you
start to work together and here's some techniques for how you might do that we're hoping to provide a set of tools that enables that to happen differently
on the other side we had a set of plays that were targeted at what we call service providers mainly that was the
the city of Atlanta and the different agencies that it that it contained but it was also meant for kind of the large
third sector organisations that have massive programming initiatives and in those neighborhoods so something like
the Atlanta Community Food Bank who already do really great work but they're a nonprofit that operates there that we
wanted to have a way to speak to the kinds of programs that they're doing in the ways in which they kind of identify
and work with community partners and what the what the playbook does I think in the and the large-scale is it
provides a common framework and language for understanding what community engagement is and where the points of
intersection might be across these kind of two sides of what's going on the
other thing that it does and why I think it's important for HCI right so I've
come this far and I haven't talked about technology yet is that it's it becomes a
map for thinking about these alternate forms of interactions and interfaces within the realm of digital civics that
are that are not about deliberation but are about the work that has to happen to bring a community together and to
mobilize and organize their efforts and then the work that has happened on the other side as city governments need to
recognize and understand how do you how do you work within a place that has a history and is trying to accomplish
goals it may be not immediately apparent right and in thinking about the kind of
turnover that you get in public office and also in kind of public sector work
this becomes important as a way to build out that organizational history and intelligence to say well we know we can
